Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI will study representations of quivers and is currently collaborating with Jerzy Weyman on an introductory book. The relationship between quivers with potentials and cluster algebras that has been explored in joint work with Weyman and Zelevinsky will be studied further. He will also study Classical Invariant Theory related to Schur-Weyl duality. This leads to a generalization of a theorem by Schrijver and a "super" version of wheeled PROPs. He also will apply Invariant Theory to (Algebraic) Complexity Theory and investigate the complexity of the Graph Isomorphism Problem. The PI will try to generalize the invariant for polymatroids that he has introduced to knots. He will also continue his collaboration with David Masser on recurrence sequences, and linear equations over multiplicative groups.

A fundamental problem is to determine whether 2 objects are essentially the same. In the Graph Isomorphism, for example, one would like to determine whether two given graphs are the same after reordering of the vertices. The PI is working on an algorithm that can be proven to be efficient for various classes of graphs. One way to distinguish objects is by using invariants. An invariant is a function on objects that may have distinct values for objects that are not the same. The PI has introduced such an invariant for graphs, and would like to extend this invariant to knots. A quiver representation is just a directed graph, where the vertices represent vector spaces and the arrows represent linear maps. Quiver representations are related to quantum groups and string theory, and the PI will investigate some of the theoretical aspects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

A tensor is a mult-dimensional array. Tensors generalize vectors (1-dimensional arrays) and matrices (2-dimensional arrays). A fundamental problem for tensors is finding a decomposition of a given tensor T as a sum of simple tensors. The fewest number of simple tensors for which this is possible is the rank of the tensor T. Finding the rank of a tensor is computationally difficult, even though for matrices it is easy. Principal Investigator Harm Derksen gave a reduction of the tensor rank problem to the matrix completion problem. Although the matrix completion problem is also difficult, there are  good heuristic methods for it. Together with Teitler, the PI improved lower bounds for certain symmetric tensors. 

The PI also developed a different approach to tensors. Rather than minimize the rank in a tensor decomposition, one could find a decomposition that optimizes the nuclear norm. The PI has given several examples of tensors for which the nuclear norm can be computed, but for which the exact rank is unknown.

A quiver Q is just a direct graph. If we attach vector spaces to the vertices of Q and linear maps with the appropiate domain and codomain to the arrows of Q, then we get a representation of the quiver Q. Many important problems in linear algebra can be formulated in terms of quiver representations. A problem studied by the PI and his graduate student Visu Makam is the behavior of m-tuples of n x n matrices under simultaneous left and right multiplication  with matrices with determinant 1. (Such m-tuples can be viewed as representations of the so-called generalized Kronecker quiver.) They proved that the ring of all invariant polynomial functions on such m-tuples are generated by invariants of low degree (there is a polynomial degree bound). These results generalize to arbitrary quivers. Also, there are various connections to theoretical computer science, and the problem of tensor ranks mentioned above.

 

Broader Impact

The PI has supervised a graduate student (Visu Makam) during part of this project which has resulted in a fruitful collaboration that will extend into the future. The PI also has supervised undergraduate student research.  A book with Jerzy Weyman on quiver representations gives a gentle introduction to the subject for beginning graduate students and was nearly completed at the end of this project.
